glen ridge municipal code 2004 ____________ a codification of the general ordinances of the borough of glen ridge new jersey ____________ beginning with supp no 9 supplemented by municipal ____________ preface the borough of glen ridge new jersey municipal originally published by book publishing company in 199 has been kept current by regular supplementation by matthew bender & company inc its successor in interest beginning with supplement no 9 municipal will be keeping this code current by regular supplementation during original codification the ordinances were compiled edited and indexed by the editorial staff of book publishing company under the direction of john n malyska and kathryn schatzkoles attorneys for the borough the code is organized by subject matter under an expandable threefactor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions each section number designates in sequence the numbers of the title chapter and section thus located in of title 2 in most instances sections are numbered by tens 010 020 030 etc leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions similarly chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion in parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section this legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table following the text of the code listing by number all ordinances their subjects and where they appear in the codification  and beginning with supplement no 9 legislation can be tracked using the table and disposition list a subjectmatter index with complete crossreferencing locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers this supplement brings the to date no 164 passed  municipal capital circle sw tallahassee fl 32310 8002622633 how to use your code this code is organized to make the laws of the borough as accessible as possible to borough officials borough employees and private citizens please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code numbering system the numbering system is the backbone of a ordinances  municipal uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this is based on three tiers beginning with title then chapter and ending with section each part is represented in the code section number for example in of title 2 title a title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled this code contains about 15 to 20 titles for example the first title is title 1 general provisions which may contain ordinances about the general penalty code adoption and definitions the titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference some titles are reserved for later use deal with more specific subjects and are often derived from one ordinance all of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title the chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material for example borough manager can be added between 204 borough council and borough attorney section of the code contains substantive ordinance material the sections are numbered by tens to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering tables of contents there are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information at the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title in addition each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections respectively note at the end of each code section you will find an ordinance history note which lists the underlying ordinances for that section the ordinances are listed by number section if applicable and year example  1992 beginning with supplement no 9 a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end these history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index statutory references the statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality as the statutes are revised these references will be updated crossreference table when a code is based on an earlier codification the crossreference table will help users find older or prior code references in the new code the crossreference table is located near the end of the code under the tabbed divider tables this table lists the prior code section in the column labeled prior  and the new code section in the column labeled herein as of supplement no 9 this table will no longer be updated disposition table to find a specific ordinance in the code turn to the section called tables for the disposition table this very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code the table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance if the ordinance is codified the chapter or chapters will be indicated example 204 612 904 if the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified such as budgets taxes annexations or rezones the disposition will be special if the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code usually at the direction of the municipality the disposition will be not codified other dispositions sometimes used are tabled pending number not used or missing beginning with supplement no 9 this table will be replaced with the table and disposition list table and disposition list beginning with supplement no 9 a table and disposition list has been added for use in tracking legislative history located in the back of this volume this table is a chronological listing of each ordinance considered for codification the table and disposition list specifies the ordinance number adoption date description of the ordinance and the disposition within the code of each ordinance by use of the table and disposition list the reader can locate any section of the code as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein index if you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code start with the index this is an alphabetical multitier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference and crossreferences where necessary look for the main heading of the subject you need then the appropriate subheadings business license see also business tax fee  required when  the index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended instruction sheet each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an instruction sheet the instruction sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement it will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current removed pages should be kept for future reference page numbers when originally published the pages of this code were consecutively numbered as of supplement no 9 when new pages are inserted with amendments the pages will follow a point numbering system example 32 321 322   33 backs of pages that are blank in codes that are printed doublesided will be left unnumbered but the number will be reserved for later use electronic submission in the interests of accuracy and speed we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible we can accept most any file format including word wordperfect or text files if you have a choice we prefer word any version you can send files to us as an email attachment by ftp on a diskette or cdrom electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is errorfree our email address is ords@municodecom  for hard copy send two copies of all ordinances passed to municipal po box 2235 tallahassee fl 32316 customer service if you have any questions about this code or our services please contact municipal at 18002622633 or municipal capital circle sw tallahassee fl 32310 82016 included 10 title 1  general provisions chapters code adoption reserved general provisions definitions the following words and phrases whenever used in the ordinances of the borough shall be construed as defined in this section unless from the context a different meaning is intended or unless a different meaning is specifically defined and more particularly directed to the use of such words or phrases borough and municipality mean the borough of glen ridge new jersey or the area within the territorial limits of the municipality and such territory outside glen ridge over which the borough has jurisdiction or control by virtue of any constitutional or statutory provision council means the council of the borough all its members or all councilmembers means the total number of councilmembers holding office county means the county of essex law denotes applicable federal law the constitution and statutes of the state of new jersey the ordinances of the borough and when appropriate any and all rules and regulations which may be promulgated thereunder may is permissive month means a calendar month must and shall are each mandatory oath includes an affirmation or declaration in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath and in such cases the words swear and sworn shall be equivalent to the words affirm and affirmed owner applied to a building or land includes any part owner joint owner tenant in common joint tenant tenant by the entirety of the whole or a part of such building or land person includes a natural person joint venture joint stock company partnership association club company corporation business trust organization or the manager lessee agent servant officer or employee of any of them personal property includes money goods chattels things in action and evidences of debt preceding and following mean text before and next after respectively property includes real and personal property real property includes lands tenements and hereditaments sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians single family means one or more persons occupying a dwelling as the term dwelling is defined in the glen ridge  as a single nonprofit housekeeping unit the term single family does not include any of the following a any occupancy which results in noncompliance with the following occupancy restrictions 1 area for sleeping purposes every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant shall contain at least seventy square feet of floor area exclusive of closets and every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one person shall contain at least fifty square feet of floor area exclusive of closets for each occupant thereof 2 prohibited occupancy kitchens bathrooms toilet rooms closets halls storage or utility spaces unfinished basements or attics and similar areas are not spaces which may be occupied for sleeping purposes  b commercial residences  c nonfamilial institutional uses  or d boarding homes or rooming houses nothing in the foregoing definition of single family shall prohibit any senior citizen who is the owner of a singlefamily dwelling which is his or her primary residence from renting or leasing a room or rooms within that dwelling together with general use associated with that dwelling to one person for purposes hereof a senior citizen is any person who has attained the age of sixtytwo years or is the spouse of such person or is the surviving spouse of that person if such surviving spouse is fiftyfive years of age or older singlefamily use means use of a dwelling as the term dwelling is defined in the glen ridge  by a singlefamily nothing in the foregoing definition of singlefamily use shall prohibit any senior citizen who is the owner of a singlefamily dwelling which is his or her primary residence from renting or leasing a room or rooms within that dwelling together with general use associated with that dwelling to one person for purposes hereof a senior citizen is any person who has attained the age of sixtytwo years or is the spouse of such person or is the surviving spouse of that person if such surviving spouse is fiftyfive years of age or older state means the state of new jersey street includes all streets highways avenues lanes alleys courts places curbs or other public ways in the borough which have been or may hereafter be dedicated and open to public use or such other public property so designated in any law of this state tenant and occupant applied to a building or land include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land whether alone or with others written includes printed typewritten mimeographed multigraphed or otherwise reproduced in permanent visible form year means a calendar year  1999   1993   title of office use of the title of any officer employee department board or commission means that officer employee department board or commission of the borough or where the particular title has been amended the title refers to and includes successor titles  1993   interpretation of language all words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning  1993   grammatical interpretation the following grammatical rules shall apply in the ordinances of the borough unless it is apparent from the context that a different construction is intended a gender each gender includes the masculine feminine and neuter genders b singular and plural the singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular c tenses words used in the present tense include the past and future tenses and vice versa unless manifestly inapplicable  1993   acts by agents when an act is required by an ordinance the same being such that it may be done as well by an agent as by the principal such requirement shall be construed to include all such acts performed by an authorized agent  1993   prohibited acts include causing and permitting whenever in the ordinances of the borough any act or omission is made unlawful it shall include causing allowing permitting aiding abetting suffering or concealing the fact of such act or omission  1993   computation of time except when otherwise provided the time within which an act is required to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last day unless the last day is sunday or a holiday in which case it shall also be excluded  1993   construction the provisions of the ordinances of the borough and all proceedings under them are to be construed with a view to effect their objects and to promote justice  1993   repeal shall not revive any ordinances the repeal of an ordinance shall not repeal the repealing clause of an ordinance or revive any ordinance which has been repealed thereby  1993 general penalty general penalty a any person violating any of the provisions or failing to comply with any of the mandatory requirements of any ordinance of the borough is guilty of a misdemeanor except in cases where a different punishment is prescribed by any ordinance of the borough any person convicted of a misdemeanor under the ordinances of the borough shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two thousand dollars by imprisonment not to exceed ninety days or by such fine community service and imprisonment b each such person is guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during any portion of which any violation of any provision of the ordinances of the borough is committed continued or permitted by any such person and said person is punishable accordingly  1993  2142011   title 2  administration and personnel chapters borough administrator created the position of borough administrator is created and the employment of a borough administrator is authorized  1986   appointment and term of office appointment to the office of borough administrator shall be made by the mayor with the advice and consent of the borough council the borough administrator shall hold office at the pleasure of the mayor and borough council  part 1986   removal from office the borough administrator may be removed only by a twothirds vote of the borough council the resolution of removal shall become effective in accordance with the provisions of njsa 40a9138  part 1986   fulltime commitmentother duties allowed the borough administrator shall devote full time to the duties of the office except that nothing herein shall prevent the administrator from also holding any other appointive office within the municipality and fulfilling the duties thereof  1986   compensation the administrator shall receive such compensation as shall be prescribed by the salary ordinance of the borough  1986   duties a the borough administrator shall administer the business affairs of the borough under the supervision and control of the mayor and borough council to the extent not prohibited by law the borough administrator shall 1 implement all policies formulated by the governing body  2 supervise and direct the activities of all department heads  3 employ and remove from employment all personnel of the borough except department heads and except where prohibited by law  4 recommend to the governing body for adoption such measures as the borough administrator may deem necessary or expedient and advise the governing body on all background matters as an aid to establishment of policy  5 advise the governing body on all matters of administrative organization and personnel and upon matters affecting the boroughs relations with the public  6 assist the governing body in the preparation of the annual budget make recommendations thereon and after the adoption of the annual budget assure that the same is properly carried out  7 be responsible for all aspects of financial management including investments certification of bills for their correctness and sufficiency of funds therefor and proper documentation with respect to such bills  8 negotiate contracts for the borough as authorized by and subject to the approval of the mayor and borough council  9 assure that all benefits and advantages to the borough or its inhabitants provided for in any statute franchise or other contract are received and upon learning of any violation call the same to the attention of the mayor and borough council  10 oversee the effect of any contracts entered into by the borough  11 assist the mayor and borough council or any designated committee in all collective bargaining negotiations  12 implement a procedure for the hiring disciplining and discharging of borough employees in accordance with appropriate statutes and collective bargaining agreements in effect with the borough  13 advise the governing body of all county state and federal programs for which the borough may qualify and which may be of benefit to the borough or its inhabitants and upon direction by the governing body arrange for the preparation execution and filing of any applications or other information which may be required for participation in such programs  14 attend all meetings of the borough council except when excused therefrom  15 perform such other duties as may be required by the governing body b for purposes of this chapter the term governing body shall include the mayor the full membership of the borough council and any committees established pursuant to the bylaws of the borough council said committees to utilize the borough administrator to direct and implement the decisions and findings of the committees the borough administrator shall also serve in a staff capacity to all advisory committees appointed by the mayor  1986   deputy borough clerk there is established the office of deputy borough clerk in the borough of glen ridge the deputy shall act according to state statute and borough ordinances in the absence of the borough clerk with all powers responsibilities and liabilities of the borough clerk  1996 assistant administrator established there is established the office of assistant administrator in the borough of glen ridge  1998   function the function of the assistant administrator is to assist the borough administrator in the performance of his or her duties and to stand in place and stead of the borough administrator during the time of his or her unavailability  1998   duties the assistant administrator may be assigned other positions or responsibilities in the borough as may be determined from time to time to be necessary and in accordance with statute or ordinance  1998   compensation the assistant administrator shall be compensated in an amount determined by the mayor and council and contained within the salary ordinance of the borough  1998 assistant borough attorney created there is created a position of assistant borough attorney  1984   function the function of the assistant borough attorney is to assist the borough attorney in the performance of his or her duties and to stand in the place and stead of the borough attorney during the times of his or her unavailability  1984   duties he or she shall attend and give his or her legal counsel at council meetings he or she shall also attend related activities at the direction of the mayor and council  1984   termcompensation the assistant borough attorney shall be appointed for a term of one year and shall be compensated in an amount determined by the mayor and council  1984 assistant borough prosecutor created there is created a position of assistant borough prosecutor  1986   function the function of the assistant borough prosecutor is to assist the borough prosecutor in the performance of his or her duties and to stand in the place and stead of the borough prosecutor during the times of his or her unavailability  1986   duties he or she shall attend and give his or her legal counsel at municipal court sessions he or she shall also attend related activities at the direction of the municipal court judge  1986   termcompensation the assistant borough prosecutor shall be appointed for a term of one year and shall be compensated in an amount determined by the mayor and council  1986 joint municipal tax assessor established pursuant to and in accordance with the provisions of njsa b1 et seq and particularly thereof there is authorized and established jointly with the borough of verona the office of joint municipal tax assessor to assess real and personal property for taxation within the borough of glen ridge and the borough of verona  1972   appointmentnecessary personnelapportionment of office expenses the governing bodies of the boroughs of glen ridge and verona shall by agreement provide for the appointment of a joint municipal tax assessor and other necessary personnel for the apportionment of the costs and expenses of operation of such office between the boroughs of glen ridge and verona and such other terms and conditions as may be necessary and convenient for the establishment and maintenance of the office the apportionment of costs and expenses may be based upon apportionment valuations determined under njsa 9 number of taxable properties population budgets and such other factor or factors or any combination thereof as may be provided in the agreement the agreement shall be subject to approval by resolution of the governing bodies of the boroughs of glen ridge and verona prior to its execution by such officials as may be authorized to execute such agreement a copy of every pertinent ordinance resolution agreement and every amendment thereto shall be filed with the director of the division of taxation in the department of the treasury and the director of the division of local finance in the department of community affairs of the state of new jersey  1972   termreappointmentremoval the office of joint municipal tax assessor shall consist of a tax assessor and such subordinate personnel as may be deemed necessary and proper to perform the assessment function in accordance with law any person who may hereafter be appointed to office position or employment as a joint municipal tax assessor shall hold such office position or employment for a term of four years as shall be provided for by agreement of the governing bodies of the boroughs of glen ridge and verona provided that any such person reappointed as joint municipal tax assessor after serving four years in that capacity shall thereafter hold his or her position during good behavior and efficiency notwithstanding that such reappointment was for a fixed term of years and he or she shall not be removed therefrom for political reasons but only for good cause shown and after a proper hearing before the director of the division of taxation of the state of new jersey or his or her designee  1972   employees all employees in the office of joint municipal tax assessor shall be deemed to be the employees of the borough having the largest apportionment valuation determined under njsa 49 as of final passage of ordinance  1972   function of assessorrecords the assessment function of the joint municipal tax assessor shall be exercised in the same manner and to the same extent as though it were exercised in each borough separately and the tax list and duplicate property record cards and all other records for each of the boroughs shall be maintained separately and shall be available for public inspection pursuant to law  1972   deputy tax collector there is established the office of deputy tax collector in the borough of glen ridge the deputy shall act according to state statute and borough ordinances in the absence of the tax collector with all powers responsibilities and liabilities of the tax collector  1996   termination of joint agreement the joint agreement may be terminated upon the adoption of a resolution to that effect by the governing body of either the borough of glen ridge or the borough of verona except by unanimous agreement such termination shall not be made effective earlier than june 30th next succeeding the expiration of twelve full calendar months following the adoption of such resolution by only one of the boroughs  1972 borough historian established there is established the position of borough historian for the borough  1975   appointment the mayor may nominate and by and with the consent of the borough council shall appoint a historian  1975   duties the borough historian shall collect and maintain all data information andor objects that are or may be of historical value or significance to the borough  1975   term the borough historian shall hold office unless sooner removed for a period of one year  1975 chief financial officer created the position of chief financial officer of the borough is created and the appointment of a chief financial officer is authorized  1990   appointment and term of office appointment to the office of chief financial officer shall be made by the mayor with the advice and consent of the borough council the chief financial officer shall hold office and gain tenure in accordance with njsa 40a91401 et seq as amended by of the public laws of 1988  1990   removal from office the chief financial officer may only be removed from office in accordance with the provisions of njsa 40a91401 et seq as amended by of the public laws of 1988  1990   qualification the chief financial officer shall hold a municipal finance officers certificate issued by the division of local government services of the new jersey department of community affairs in accordance with njsa 40a91401 et seq  1990   other duties allowed nothing in this chapter shall prevent the chief financial officer from also holding any other appointive office within the municipality and fulfilling the duties thereof  1990   compensation the chief financial officer shall receive such compensation as shall be prescribed by the salary ordinance of the borough  1990   duties the chief financial officer shall administer the financial affairs of the borough under the supervision and control of the borough administrator and the mayor and borough council to the extent not prohibited by law the chief financial officer shall a implement all of the financial policies formulated by the governing body  b supervise and direct the financial activities of the borough  c recommend to the governing body for adoption matters of importance to the financial planning and integrity of the municipality  d assist the governing body in the preparation of the annual budget make recommendations thereon and after the adoption of the budget assure that implementation of and accounting for same is properly carried out  e be responsible for all aspects of financial management including investments certification of bills for their correctness and sufficiency of funds therefor and proper documentation with respect to such bills  f be responsible for compliance with all statutes pertaining to municipal finance as well as complying with all municipal financial regulations of the state of new jersey  g perform other such duties as may be required by the governing body  1990   deputy treasurer there is established the office of deputy treasurer in the borough of glen ridge the deputy shall act according to state statute and borough ordinances in the absence of the treasurer with all powers responsibilities and liabilities of the treasurer  1996 police department qualifications for appointment before any person can hereafter be appointed a member of the police department he or she shall fulfill the following qualifications for membership a an applicant must have 1 an associates degree signifying completion of the undergraduate curriculum and graduation from an accredited college or university or 2 have completed sixty semester hours of college credits from an accredited college or university alternatively 3 an applicant must have two years of military service with any branch of the united states government or two years of law enforcement experience  combined with thirty semester hours of college credits from an accredited college or university  b meet the residence requirements specified by applicable law  c be a legally qualified voter  d never have been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude  e meet the age requirements specified by state law  f be of good health and sound in body and mind  g present a satisfactory medical certificate  h be of good moral character  i meet the qualifications necessary for membership in the police and firemans retirement system state of new jersey  j satisfactorily pass all applicant examinations written and oral and other requirements that may reasonably be deemed necessary by the public safety committee  k never have been a member of any party or group or organization advocating the overthrow of the government of the united states or any state thereof  and l be licensed by the state of new jersey to operate motor vehicles  2002  art i  4 1964   appointmentphysical exam no person shall hereafter be appointed a paid member designated by the public safety committee for such purpose appears from such physical examination incapable of performing duties required of him or her in the department with efficiency and safety art i  5 1964   headquartersreporting for duty the headquarters of the department shall be located at the police station and all members of the department will unless otherwise ordered report there for duty art i  6 1964   chief of policepowers and duties the chief of police shall have the following powers and shall perform the following duties a the chief of police shall be the chief executive officer of the police department and shall be subject to the control of the public safety committee the public safety committee as the appropriate authority may relinquish their authority temporarily or permanently to a position higher than the chief of police note if the chief of police and director of public safety are one person in the same the appropriate authority must move up another level of authority ie borough administrator under these rules and regulations the chief shall see that federal and state laws and county resolutions and borough ordinances are enforced by the persons under his or her command the chief shall make a monthly report in writing to the chairperson of the public safety committee of the activity and performance of the department and at the first regular meeting of the mayor and council held in january and july of each year shall report on the personnel and general condition of the force in such form as may be prescribed or required by the public safety committee the chief shall keep in his or her office an individual personnel record of every member of the police department and in it record the name age place of residence date of appointment police training schools attended and marks or grades obtained heroic acts performed outstanding arrests made and any disciplinary action taken against any member or any other pertinent information regarding such member and date and cause of removal from the department this file shall in all cases be available to the public safety committee when appointments or promotions are to be recommended by it b in case of the occurrence of any vacancy in the department from any cause the chief shall notify the public safety committee at once of such fact the chief shall receive charges filed against any member of the police department and present same to the public safety committee including charges against himself or herself and when charges made against any member by someone not the mayor or a member of the police department or of the borough council the chief of police shall require the person making the charges to verify them the chief shall in any case cause the member against whom the charge is preferred to be furnished with a copy of the charge or complaint together with notice of time and place of hearing thereof and will notify or subpoena the necessary witnesses the chief shall have the power to suspend forthwith any member against whom charges are made as aforesaid pending the investigation of such charges and shall immediately report any such suspension to the chairperson of the public safety committee or in his or her absence to any member of the borough council c upon such suspension of any member of the department sidearms identification cards and shields shall be taken up and held by the chief of police or by the chairperson of the public safety committee in the case of suspension of any member of the department his or her compensation shall cease if charges are dismissed the member shall be restored to duty with backpay d the chief of police shall detail any member of the department to any special duty that he or she may deem proper in any part of the borough for any period not exceeding sixteen hours  for any longer period he or she is to consult with and obtain the consent of the chairperson of the public safety committee or in his absence any member of the public safety committee e the chief of police shall have power to promulgate orders to the department not inconsistent with any of the orders or rules herein established or with any administrative orders made by the borough council  all such orders shall be in writing and copies of them shall be filed in the file to be kept in the chiefs office for that purpose f all executive and administrative rules made by the borough council as well as all additions or amendments to said rules shall be promulgated to the department by the chief as ordered by the borough council or by the public safety committee or as he or she may deem necessary and proper g the chief shall be responsible for the deportment general condition and training of the members of the department and shall frequently call for inspection of uniforms and equipment and enforce habits of cleanliness and neat personal appearance h the chief shall be responsible for the prevention of crime or disorder and the detection of crime or disorder and the detection of criminals  and to enable the chief to accomplish such results he or she is vested with power to post the members of the department in such a way not inconsistent with the rules and regulations as herein provided as he or she may deem expedient i whenever crime or attempt at same is reported to police headquarters or in any way comes to the knowledge of the chief of police he or she shall see to it that such information is conveyed to the proper members of the department by the desk officers and shall take proper means to secure the apprehension of wanted criminals or suspects and to prevent any repetition of crimes j the chief shall check or cause to be checked all materials and supplies purchased for the department to see that they are of the quality and quantity desired and shall check all invoices to be paid out of department funds to be sure that the service or goods to be paid for were received and were in accordance with the purchase orders or requests k during times when the chief is away on leave the captain or next ranking officer shall assume responsibility of the department as the officer in charge   art ii  2 1964   sergeantspowers and duties sergeants in the department shall rank next below the lieutenants a sergeants shall be assigned to such duty as the chief of police or in the chiefs absence the captain may direct and shall promptly obey and enforce all orders received from the chief of police and other superior officers it shall be the duty of the sergeant to patrol all posts during such hours as ordered by the chief of police or in the chiefs absence the captain or duty lieutenant and to visit or communicate with the men upon their posts at such time and in such manner as will best insure the faithful and efficient performance of duty when on desk duty a sergeant shall conform to all rules and regulations governing the actions of a desk officer b the sergeants shall promptly report to the chief of police every case of dereliction of duty or improper conduct or violation of any of the rules and regulations by any patrol officer or probational patrol officer and immediately upon becoming acquainted therewith shall make written charges and specifications thereon and shall write at the bottom of such charges and specifications the names of the witnesses the sergeants shall also promptly report in writing to the chief of police any special services by any member of the force which the sergeants deem meritorious art ii  5 1964   desk officerpowers and duties there shall be an officer of the police department on duty in charge of the desk at headquarters at all times of the day and night and hisher place while on duty shall be behind the desk this officer shall be known as the desk officer a while on duty the desk officer shall have control and charge of headquarters and shall be responsible for the cleanliness and good order of the same and for the good conduct discipline and efficiency of all members on duty b the desk officer shall remain on duty until properly relieved and shall report to the relieving officer all orders all important police news occurring during hisher tour of duty and all duties required to be carried out c the desk officer shall not leave his post during his tour of duty except for physical necessity official duty within headquarters or upon urgent police business d when required to leave post for any reason heshe shall place a competent member in charge of the desk during hisher absence and shall enter the facts in each case in the form of a memorandum to the chief of police e the desk officer shall not permit any unauthorized person behind the desk and shall not permit any member of the department to linger or loiter in the desk area f the desk officer shall be responsible for the prompt neat accurate and complete recording of all information reports records and other data required to be made by said officer g the desk officer shall see that the telephone teletype and radio instruments and equipment are operating properly and not tampered with and that all calls and signals are promptly and properly answered h the desk officer shall promptly attend to all messages received by telephone or otherwise and shall enter the message and the action taken thereon in the records i the desk officer shall immediately report to the chief of police or in hisher absence the captain all unusual and important messages or information received j the desk officer shall be tactful courteous and attentive in taking all messages from citizens and in dealing with all such persons k the desk officer shall cooperate to the fullest extent with other borough departments and shall promptly forward to such departments all messages and reports affecting them l the desk officer shall be responsible for and shall carefully account for all money and other property taken from prisoners accident victims or from persons finding the same heshe shall list property in detail with description money by amount and details of coin and bills the name and address of the person from whom the property is received and other pertinent data heshe shall sign this record showing the date and time received and see that all such money and property is promptly locked up in a secure place in headquarters  heshe shall thereafter report to the chief of police that same has been done m the desk officer shall inspect all members reporting for duty or going on post and make sure that each member is properly dressed and is neat in appearance  that heshe is carrying the full equipment required  and that heshe is physically fit and in proper condition to do fully duty the desk officer shall assign each member to tour of duty instruct the member as to any special orders for that tour of duty and record the time each member goes on duty n the desk officer shall receive the report of each member of the department coming off duty heshe will be held responsible for accepting any incomplete report heshe shall not release a patrol officer until his report has been passed upon and accepted heshe shall record the time each member goes off duty o the desk officer shall report to the chief of police any member late or absent or not in proper condition or not properly dressed or equipped either when reporting on or going off duty p the desk officer shall cause immediate investigation to be made to ascertain the whereabouts and condition of any member who may fail to report for duty or when going off duty q the desk officer shall report to the chief of police any complaint report or other evident of misconduct or neglect of duty or inefficiency on the part of any member of the department r whenever the desk officer has any reason to suspect a member of the department of being intoxicated or whenever any person is taken into custody under suspicion of being intoxicated and legal proof of such condition is desirable evidence said officer shall immediately obtain the services of the police surgeon designated by the mayor and council or the best available substitute doctor for a prompt examination of the suspected person s the desk officer shall inspect as soon as practicable the reports turned in by members coming off duty shall transcribe to official records all pertinent information contained therein and shall take such police action on the facts as may be proper t the desk officer shall promptly notify the county physician or prosecutors office of the facts in any case of violent or sudden death in the borough that may come to attention u upon receiving an alarm of a fire from any source the desk officer shall detail one or more members to report to the scene of the fire upon receipt of an alarm from a source other than the fire alarm system the desk officer shall ascertain the location of the fire and immediately notify the fire department v the desk officer shall accept the report of any person wishing to report a traffic accident and obtain all possible pertinent data as well as the name and address of the reporting person w when a crime is reported to the desk officer heshe shall take immediate steps to obtain all the facts of the case as quickly as possible x the desk officer shall detain witnesses in serious crimes unless they shall be properly vouched for and attempt at all times to procure written statements from all witnesses such statements are to be made out in triplicate one copy being given the witness y when a person makes a complaint against another before the desk officer the desk officer shall advise the complainant of his or her right to sign a complaint and shall have the matter properly investigated z when prisoners are in the cell block or detention room the desk officer shall inspect the same every half hour to see that everything is in proper order when a woman is locked in the detention room the desk officer shall call a woman appointed to act as matron if the woman is sent to any institution the matron and a police officer must accompany the prisoner when a prisoner is brought to headquarters by any member of the department and charged with the commission of any offense the desk officer is only to ascertain whether the act with which the prisoner is charged constitutes an offense for which a person can be lawfully detained and whether there is reasonable ground for the complaint the desk officer will then record the arrest and cause the prisoner to be locked up and will take the necessary measures to insure the prompt appearance of the prisoner and all witnesses and complaining officers before the magistrate no police officer is authorized by law to discharge any prisoner from custody art ii  6 1964   patrol officerspowers and duties in carrying out the function of the department namely the preservation of public peace protection of life and property the prevention of crime the arrest of violators of the laws and ordinances every patrol officer shall constantly direct his or her best efforts to accomplish that end patrol officers shall act intelligently and efficiently and hold themselves in readiness at all times to answer the calls and obey the order of superiors a patrol officers shall frequently during their tour of patrol duty in the nighttime carefully examine doors and windows of premises known to be unoccupied to determine whether they are properly secured and shall report to the desk officer immediately or as soon as practicable if doors or windows are found unsecured b patrol officers shall report to the desk officer all suspicious circumstances or persons and all information pertaining to them which may be in their possession they shall particularly take notice of persons and vehicles and if they observe anything suspicious they shall investigate same and satisfy themselves that same are engaged in legitimate pursuits c patrol officers shall report to the desk officer at headquarters at the termination of their tour of night duty all street lamps that may not be lit at the proper time or are in any way out of order d patrol officers must give their name and shield number to all persons who may ask for same e if patrol officers observe anything on the street likely to produce danger or public inconvenience or anything which seems to them irregular or offensive they shall take such action as shall obviate the danger and also report same as soon as practicable to the desk officer on duty f patrol officers must to the utmost of their ability prevent the commission of assaults breaches of the peace any crime about to be committed in their presence or any violation of the county resolutions borough ordinances and federal and state laws including traffic laws and regulations g patrol officers must by their vigilance render it difficult for anyone to commit a crime the absence of crime being considered a good indication of police efficiency when a crime has been committed if there is good cause to suspect that negligence is attributable to the member of the department on post or on patrol a charge of neglect of duty shall be preferred against him or her h when any person charges another with the commission of a crime and insists that the person shall be arrested a patrol officer shall if there be sufficient ground for arrest require the accuser to accompany him or her to headquarters along with the accused and there prefer the charge as soon as this is done the officer having been absent from his or her post shall return to same as soon as possible nothing herein contained shall be deemed to forbid a member of the department to make an immediate arrest with or without a warrant in cases where an arrest by a peace officer is permitted by the laws of this state i in case of fire burglary riot or any other emergency the patrol officer on duty nearest the scene of same shall immediately send in such information to the desk officer and in the meantime take such action as the emergency may require j when on duty except in patrol cars patrol officers must not talk with each other except to communicate information pertaining to their police duties  and in such cases they must make the communications as brief as possible they shall not ride or walk with persons on their beat except in proper police duty they shall not engage in lengthy conversation with citizens while on duty lest neglect of duty result k in case a patrol officer be taken sick while on patrol duty he or she will report to the desk officer so that hisher post may be covered art ii  7 1964   probational patrol officerspowers and duties applications for appointment as probational patrol officers shall be made to the public safety committee in care of the chief a from persons enrolled as applicants and found eligible by the public safety committee the said committee shall recommend to the mayor in the order of qualifications as the needs of the department may require the appointment of probational patrol officers upon the recommendation of the public safety committee and with the approval of the borough council the mayor shall make appointments of probational patrol officers for a period not to exceed one year b probational patrol officers shall be assigned to the same regular duties as patrol officers they shall be considered candidates for the office of patrol officer c probational patrol officers shall not be appointed patrol officers until they shall have established to the satisfaction of the public safety committee that they fulfill all the qualifications for membership as provided for in d in the performance of duty probational patrol officers are subject to the same rules and regulations as patrol officers probational patrol officers shall enforce all federal and state laws county resolutions and borough ordinances e at any time when the public safety committee shall be convinced that a probational patrol officer does not possess the strength activity energy good judgment fidelity and habits necessary for a patrol officer or that he or she is failing either in capacity or character or that the necessity for his or her temporary employment no longer exists such person shall be dismissed from the department art ii  8 1964   general rules and regulations 1 every member of the department shall study and familiarize themself with the rules and regulations and orders of the department the resolutions of the county ordinances of the borough and the laws of the united states and state of new jersey pertaining to his or her position and duties ignorance of any of them will not be an excuse for violation thereof 2 every member of the department shall devote his or her whole time and attention to the service of the department and is expressly prohibited from following any other calling or being engaged in any other business although certain hours are allotted for the performance of regular tours of duty every member of the department is considered to be at all times subject to call for duty and must act promptly at any time that his or her services are required 3 a member assigned to duty in any rank higher than his own shall be governed by the rules and regulations and general orders affecting such higher rank the general rules and regulations for patrol officers shall apply to all members on any duty 4 every member shall at all times serve the best interests of the department by observing and reporting all matters pertaining to and concerning its welfare members shall not conduct themselves in such a manner as to deceive or to evade or violate any law ordinance rule or regulation 5 members shall not conduct themselves in a manner unbecoming a police officer and a gentleman or gentlewoman they shall not use obscene immoral or improper language and shall at all times and under all conditions be respectful and courteous to all 6 in the performance of his or her duties every member of the department must maintain decorum command of temper patience and discretion  must at all times refrain from harsh coarse profane or insolent language yet be firm resolute and energetic  must never use unnecessary force every member of the department must be punctual in his or her attendance to all calls and requirements of duty and at all times yield prompt and implicit obedience to the orders of his or her superior officers 7 intoxication whether while on or off duty shall be considered one of the most serious offenses and no member of the department shall while on duty drink any intoxicating liquor nor while on duty except in the immediate discharge of police duty enter any place where intoxicating liquors are sold or furnished while wearing any portion of his or her police uniform nor shall any intoxicating liquor be introduced upon any pretext into headquarters except that to be held as evidence or on the advice of a physician and then only in the amount necessary or prescribed to meet the needs of the special emergency 8 no member of the department shall indulge in or permit unlicensed gambling on or off duty 9 no member of the department shall solicit or accept either directly or indirectly any gratuity reward or gift from any person nor shall heshe solicit or accept compensation for damages sustained in the discharge of hisher duties without permission of the chairperson of the public safety committee 10 no member of the department shall engage in political or religious discussions or critical discussion of the management of the borough government while on duty 11 no member of the department shall assign hisher salary or any part thereof nor incur any liability which heshe is unwilling or unable to promptly pay nor shall heshe refuse or neglect to honorably discharge and promptly pay all just indebtedness 12 no member of the department shall smoke while outdoors in uniform nor while on any regular or special assignment indoors at any public place or gathering except under conditions prescribed by the chief of police 13 no member of the department shall make engagements for special services  all applications for such special service must be referred to the chief of police no special duty shall be performed by a member of the department without direct authority in each case from the chief of police 14 a member of the department shall exercise the utmost care in the handling of firearms and shall not demonstrate the operation of hisher revolver to any person nor permit any person to handle it except in the course of authorized revolver practice 15 no member of the department shall apply for or execute any warrant of arrest or search without the consent of the chief of police 16 no member of the department shall compound any offense committed against his or her person or property nor withdraw any complaint unless permitted by the public safety committee 17 a member of the department dismissed suspended with or without pay or residing therefrom shall immediately surrender to the chief of police hisher shield revolver identification card all other issued equipment and all property of the department which may be in hisher possession 18 a member of the department finding stray animals running at large shall at once report such fact to the desk officer at headquarters 19 a member of the department other than the chief of police when on duty or when attending meetings of the public safety committee as a witness or on trial for charges preferred against him or her shall appear in full uniform unless otherwise ordered when not on duty no member shall wear any portion of hisher uniform except as permitted by the chief of police 20 any member of the department who may be prevented by sickness or any other cause from reporting at headquarters at any time when it may be hisher duty so to do shall immediately cause the reason for hisher absence to be reported to the desk officer at headquarters 21 a member of the department reporting for duty must be clean shaven and neat in person with clothes clean and pressed shoes shined shield and devices polished hair properly cut and dress in conformity with the regulations 22 a member of the department when on duty in uniform shall wear the shield on the outside of hisher outermost garment and over the left breast so that the entire surface of the shield may be easily and distinctly seen it will be deemed a neglect of duty on the part of any member to carelessly lose hisher shield or other insignia of office or to neglect to fasten the same securely to hisher clothing or when losing the same to fail to report the fact promptly to the desk officer at headquarters 23 no member of the department while on duty shall leave the borough except on official authorized police business 24 a member of the department shall treat as strictly confidential all official business of the department and shall not impart it to anyone except those for whom it was intended or as directed by the chief of police 25 a member of the department shall not talk for publication be interviewed nor make public speeches or statements with respect to police business except by direct permission of the chairperson of the public safety committee or the chief of police 26 a member of the department shall not communicate to any person any information which may enable anyone to evade arrest or punishment nor shall heshe dispose of or secrete any property that is stolen or that is needed for evidence 27 a member of the department shall not withdraw a complaint a member shall not destroy or fail to turn in to the desk officer a summons once made out a member shall not suggest or recommend any attorney for any person arrested 28 a member of the department shall promptly mark for identification and secure against loss or tampering any lost stolen abandoned unclaimed or recovered property or any property of value as evidence coming into their possession said member shall deliver the same to the desk officer who shall turn it over to the chief of police 29 a member of the department shall not use the department telephone for other than official department business when answering the telephone heshe shall always give first the official designation of hisher telephone and then hisher rank and then hisher name unless otherwise instructed by the chief of police 30 a member of the department who discharges hisher firearm in the line of duty or accidentally discharges hisher firearm on or off duty shall make a report in writing to the chief of police specifying all facts concerning the incident 31 a uniformed member of the department shall not carry packages bundles or other articles unless necessary in the performance of police duty nor shall heshe carry or read newspapers or other reading matter while on patrol or post duty 32 a member of the department shall not interfere in civil cases except to prevent a breach of the peace or to quell a disturbance 33 a member of the department shall take orders only from duly authorized police or civilian personnel authorized police personnel shall include in descending order of rank the police chief captains lieutenants and sergeants should no police officers as designated herein be available the mayor chairperson of the public safety committee or a member of the committee in the order named shall be authorized to give orders to members of the department 34 no member of the department assigned to duty on any post shall come to headquarters except in an emergency or with permission of the desk officer the desk officer will be held accountable for detaining any member at headquarters for a longer period than is absolutely necessary 35 members of the department shall immediately report icy or snowy sidewalks obstacles in streets or sidewalks holes in streets or sidewalks fallen wires or trees dangerous conditions of buildings signs and poles or any other condition that might lead to an accident 36 members shall not without specific permission use their own automobiles when going on post after leaving headquarters or returning to headquarters from post but shall proceed directly and promptly to their destination in the shortest possible time without stopping anywhere en route except for proper police duty 37 no members of the department shall trade or substitute their tours of duty or their days off except on direct authority of the chief of police or the chiefs designated agent 38 when appearing in court a member of the department shall wear hisher prescribed uniform or if in civilian clothes shall be neatly dressed in suit and necktie 39 no member of the department shall on any pretense whatsoever strike assault or use threatening or insulting language to any other member of the department no member shall behave in any insubordinate or disrespectful manner toward the public safety committee the chief of police or any other member of the department while in the execution of office 40 members of the department must be civil and respectful to each other on all occasions 41 members of the department shall transact all their official business chief of police if however any member after having applied to the chief of police feels that justice has not been done may apply to the public safety committee 42 members of the department must be punctual in attendance to all calls requirements of duty court appointments and other circumstances where time is specified 43 no member of the department shall make any purchase or incur any liability for the department except on authority of the chairperson of the public safety committee or the chief of police 44 members of the department shall not enter stores garages houses or other buildings while on duty except in direct line of duty or on permission granted by the officer in charge 45 all members of the department other than the chief of police shall wear their uniforms at all times when on duty unless special permission has been granted by the chairperson of the public safety committee or the chief of police 46 it shall be the duty of every member of the department to report to the chief of police any and all violations of these rules and regulations or orders promulgated hereunder 47 no member of the department shall be allowed to receive a present from others under hisher command no subscription solicitation for subscription or contribution shall be made by any member of the department toward any present or reward intended for another member of the department unless specially authorized by the public safety committee 48 no member of the department shall directly or indirectly be concerned in making any compromise or arrangement between thieves or other criminals and persons who have suffered from their acts with a view to permitting the criminals to escape punishment and any member who has any part in such compromise or arrangements or has any knowledge thereof and fails to give information to hisher superior shall be subject to dismissal 49 all members of the department shall report to the officer in charge at headquarters the location of the dead body of any animal that comes to their attention so that it can be removed 50 members of the department detailed to special duty such as dances meetings sporting events weddings or special traffic assignments will be held as strictly accountable as though on regular duty 51 members of the department when on duty upon the street must keep the uniform coat entirely buttoned at all times and shirt sleeves are to be rolled down and buttoned 52 when on duty all members of the department when addressing superiors will address them by their rank 53 untruthfulness is a grave disqualification for the police service and will subject a member of the department to discipline when called upon to give evidence or make any deposition members of the department shall be under the direction of the court and shall in response to questions asked state truthfully in a clear and distinct voice all they know respecting the matter inquired of without fear or reservation or without any desire or design to influence the result 54 when persons are found upon the streets or public places in unconscious conditions an ambulance or a physician shall be called or they shall be brought to a hospital and medical attendance procured as quickly as possible no prisoner shall be put in a cell while unconscious 55 members of the department shall make themselves familiar with the location of fire alarm and police call boxes to be used in case of fire or when help is required or in case of accident to call the ambulance 56 no member of the department may withdraw or resign while charges are pending against him or her except by permission of the public safety committee 57 members of the department are required to report their places of residence to the chief of police with such particularity as to enable the residence to be easily found and also to report any change of residence immediately upon such change being made 58 no erasures are to be made in any of the books records reports or documents connected with the police department if any error is discovered in such books records reports or documents it is to be corrected by drawing the pen neatly across the entry and substituting the corrections above it 59 no member of the department when assigned to patrol duty shall leave hisher post until regularly relieved except in the immediate discharge of police duty or when called from hisher post by a superior officer or except to answer a call for assistance by a fellow officer or to make an arrest 60 no member of the department while on relief from post shall loiter in the roll room at headquarters 61 no member of the department assigned to use police motor vehicles shall abuse such motor vehicles by careless operating in a manner which may cause damage to them the driver of the vehicle shall be held accountable for its general condition at all times while under hisher control 62 a member of the department shall operate department vehicles in such a manner as to avoid injury to persons or damage to property and unless some police emergency prevails heshe shall comply with all traffic laws and regulations 63 it is considered neglect of duty for any member of the department to allow the vehicle assigned to him or her to run out of gas 64 a member of the department shall neither add to nor subtract from the equipment assigned to the vehicle 65 a member of the department shall not use any department vehicle for a purpose other than proper business of the department vehicles are not to be taken out of the borough unless on police business without permission from the chief of police 66 police vehicles are not to be used to push or tow any vehicle 67 members of the department shall not litter any part of the headquarters building by leaving newspapers paper or reading matter lying about 68 each member of the department is forbidden to give expression to hisher political or partisan opinions in headquarters or while in the discharge of hisher duties no member of the department will be permitted to be a delegate to or member of any political or partisan club council convention committee or society whose real purpose whether acknowledged or concealed shall be the nomination or support of any candidate for a public office or the furtherance of the objects or designs of any political organization no member of the department shall be allowed to solicit money or aid on any pretext for any political purpose whatever art iv  168 1964   uniforms a the uniforms of the officers and members of the police department shall be of the regulation pattern approved by the public safety committee b the chief of police shall specify the dates of changes for the wearing of the summer and winter uniforms c all members who have served five years in the department shall wear on both sleeves of all uniform coats a service stripe of black braid threeeighths inch wide and a similar stripe shall be added for each additional five years d veterans shall wear a red stripe in addition to the black service stripe art v  14 1964   discharge the members of the police department other than probational patrol officers shall hold their respective employments during good behavior efficient performance and such residence as is required by law except for probational patrol officers no person shall be discharged from the police department of the borough for any cause other than incapacity misconduct insubordination failure to conform to residence requirements or disobedience of rules and regulations then in effect for the police department provided that any member of the police department who shall be absent from duty without just cause for a continuous period of five days shall at the expiration of said five days cease to be a member of the police department discharge under this subsection shall only be after hearing as provided in  art i  3 1964   public safety committeepowers to discipline the control and discipline of the police department and of all its members shall be vested in the public safety committee subject to the control of the mayor and council the public safety committee is given express power to enforce all rules and regulations herein provided and to enforce the administrative and executive rules from time to time adopted by reprimand deduction of pay suspension from duty with or without pay or reduction in rank according to the nature and seriousness of the offense in case the seriousness of the offense is such or the repetition thereof is so frequent as in the opinion of the public safety committee to justify the removal from office or employment of such member or officer of the police department the public safety committee shall so report to the mayor and council and said council may direct a hearing to that end upon notice as provided in art vi  1 1964   hearings whenever the mayor and council directs that a hearing be held on charges against any member of the police department the following procedures shall be observed the charge or charges shall be made in writing and signed by the person or persons making such charge or charges the chief of police shall serve a copy of the charges upon the said accused together with a notice that the charges will be heard before the mayor and council at a time and place therein named and shall file the charge or charges with a copy of the notice and affidavit of its service with the borough clerk such notice and filing shall be at least five days before the meeting at which the charge or charges are to be heard thereupon the borough clerk shall place same upon the calendar of the mayor and council to be heard at the option of the accused at either a public or private meeting of the mayor and council at such meeting the accused may appear in person and with attorney and produce any and all witnesses and testimony to make such defense as he or she chooses to make the mayor and council shall at such meeting hear the evidence offered to substantiate or rebut the charge or charges and shall determine whether or not the accused person is guilty of the charge or charges against him or her the mayor and council may make such determination at such meeting or may in its discretion name a place and time within two weeks at which such hearing may be continued and may in its discretion announce a date within two weeks of the meeting or of the adjourned meeting at which such determination will be made if the mayor and council find the accused guilty the mayor and council may adopt a resolution dismissing or removing the accused from office or employment or may inflict such lesser penalty as is provided by the rules and regulations herein if the charges be against the chief of police such charges shall be served upon the chief of police by some person designated by the public safety committee art vi  2 1964   specific charges the following charges are to be heard as provided in hereof except as otherwise provided a intoxication  b wilful disobedience of orders  c indecent profane or harsh language  d disrespect to a superior officer  e unnecessary violence to prisoners or unlawful use of force in any case  f leaving post without just cause  g neglect in paying just debts contracted while a member of the department  h immorality indecency or lewdness  i absence without leave see also   j incompetency lack of energy and incapacity mental or physical  k entering any building or dwelling except in discharge of duty while on duty  l sleeping on duty  m neglect of duty  n violation of any criminal law  o making known the proposed action or movements of the department or the provision of any orders to persons outside of the department other than to the public safety committee  p conduct unbecoming an officer  q conduct subversive of good order and the discipline of the department  r failure to properly patrol his or her post  s absence from post  t publicly commenting on the official action of a superior  u obtaining appointment to the department by fraud or swearing falsely in making application for appointment  v untruthfulness  and w violating any of the rules and regulations governing the department or any administrative rule or regulation promulgated by the public safety committee or the mayor and council art vi  3 1964   responsibility to note charges when charges are made against a member of the police department the chief of police is to add to such charges reference to any prior charges against the accused and what disposition was made of them art vi  4 1964 police department drug testing policy statement in september 199 the state of new jersey attorney general adopted revised guidelines with respect to testing law enforcement applicants law enforcement trainees and sworn law enforcement officers for the use of controlled dangerous substances the most significant change of the guidelines establishes random drug testing of sworn law enforcement officers  part 1999   procedure the procedures hereinafter set forth in this chapter relating directly to the attorney generals law enforcement drug testing policy will be the policy of the glen ridge police department all police personnel will comply with these procedures and any and all additional addendums set by the attorney general essex county prosecutors office or the glen ridge chief of police as per the office of the essex county prosecutor essex county prosecutor memorandum #4598  the borough of glen ridge hereafter institutes the following random drugtesting program for the police department of the borough of glen ridge  part 1999   order of random drug testingsworn law enforcement officers a the random drug testing of sworn officers of the glen ridge police department will include all members regardless of rank or assignment b 1 the police commissioner a nonsworn official will randomly announce to the chief of police the date the selection process will be 2 the selection process will be conducted randomly twice a year 3 the chief of police will notify the appropriate witnesses for the selection 4 the selection process will be conducted at the office of the chief of police c present for the drawing of names will be the following witnesses 1 chief of police  2 lieutenant or sergeant  3 internal affairs officer  and 4 pba representative d 1 four officers will be randomly selected each time a selection takes place 2 the name of every sworn officer will be printed on a separate three inch by five inch card 3 the namescards will be verified by the witnesses e 1 the namescards of every sworn officer will be placed in a hat for every selection 2 the namescards will be mixed prior to selection 3 four namescards will be drawn from the hat by picking at random 4 each witness shall pick one card f 1 the collection of urine specimens from selected officers will be prompt efficient and confidential 2 the internal affairs officer is responsible for the collection and record of urine samples as outlined in the attorney generals guidelines 3 following the selection process the officers named will be contacted by the internal affairs officer at the first opportunity upon reporting to work g any member of the police department who discloses the identity of an officer selected for random testing or the fact that a random selection is scheduled to take place prior to the collection of urine specimens shall be subject to discipline h officers who refuse to submit to a drug test when randomly selected are subject to the same penalties as those officers who test positive for the illegal use of drugs see attorney generals law enforcement drug testing policy  part 1999   special considerations a an administrative decision to eliminate an officer selected is permissible if 1 the officer is not available  2 the officer is on extended leave b the decision will be documented by the internal affairs officer and made a permanent record of the testing process  part 1999   applicability of other laws nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or impair the power of the borough of glen ridge or any officer or department to enforce any provisions of its charter or any other provisions of its code or regulations promulgated thereunder nor to prevent or punish violations thereof and the powers conferred by this chapter shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred upon the borough by any other law or provision of the glen ridge  part 1999   severability if any clause sentence subdivision paragraph section or part of the ordinance codified in this chapter be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid such judgment shall not affect impair or invalidate the remainder thereof but shall be confined in its operation to the clause sentence subdivision paragraph section or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered  part 1999 fire department establishing regulations the regulations of the fire department referred to elsewhere in this chapter as the regulations shall be those made and established by the chief with the approval of the public safety committee of the mayor and council and may be amended in like manner all the regulations made in pursuance hereof shall be in writing and signed by the chairperson of the public safety committee and by the chief of the fire department and
