shall be filed in the office of the borough clerk and posted in the fire stations and shall be binding on all members of the department after such filing and posting art i  3 1964   chiefcontrol over departmentacting chief the chief shall exercise sole and complete control over the entire department both paid and volunteer members subject only to the borough council and the public safety committee the mayor and council or the public safety committee may designate a paid member of the department to serve as acting chief during the absence or disability of the chief art ii  1 1964   chiefduties generally the chief shall be the fire marshal and fire inspector of the borough the chief shall cause all appropriate measures to be taken for the saving of life limb and property from loss or damage by fire and the hazards thereof the chief shall see that all laws and ordinances effective in the borough relating to the prevention of fire are enforced the chief shall be responsible for the enforcement of the fire regulations and all special orders of the mayor and council or its public safety committee whenever possible the chief shall take command at every fire and direct the members of the department under himher in the discharge of their duties the chief shall by order detail the tours and nature of duty of the members of the department under himher with such special instructions as heshe may deem proper all details of members of the department for any special or particular duty or service shall be made by the chief or pursuant to hisher order art ii  2 1964   purchases the chief shall check or cause to be checked all materials and supplies purchased for the department to see that they are of the quality and quantity desired and shall check all invoices to be paid out of the department funds to be sure that the service or goods to be paid for were received and were in accordance with the purchase orders or requests made by himher or pursuant hisher order art ii  3 1964   chiefreports the chief shall keep a service record of each member of the department including therein a record of any violation of the regulations and any commendation or citation for excellent work or exceptional bravery in case of the occurrence of any vacancy in the department for any cause the chief shall notify the public safety committee at once of such fact the chief shall keep a full record of all fire calls and all particulars relating thereto including the time and place the type of fire and amount of loss the chief shall also keep a record of any other functions of the department the chief shall prepare and present promptly to the mayor and council monthly and annual reports of the operation of the department including the number and character of the alarms received and responded to the number of members of the department and equipment responding the location of each fire or cause of alarm and such other particulars in relation thereto as heshe or the public safety committee may deem necessary or proper art ii  4 1964   other officers the other officers of the department shall perform the duties prescribed by the regulations or assigned by the chief art ii  5 1964   surgeon in case of the unavailability of the police and fire surgeon a reputable physician of the borough may be designated to act in place by the chief acting chief or the public safety committee art ii  6 1964   member qualifications before any person can hereafter be appointed a paid probationary member of the department he or she shall fulfill the following qualifications for membership a be able to read and write the english language  b meet the residence requirements specified by state law  c be a legally qualified voter of the state of new jersey  d never have been convicted of crime involving moral turpitude  e meet the age requirements specified by state law  f be able to present a satisfactory medical certificate  g meet the qualifications necessary for membership in the police and firemans retirement system of new jersey  h satisfactorily pass all applicable examinations written and oral that may be deemed necessary by the public safety committee  and i be licensed by the state of new jersey to operate motor vehicles art iii  1 1964   applicantsphysical examination no person shall hereafter be appointed a paid member of the department who shall fail to pass the physical examination by the police and fire surgeon of the borough or who in the written opinion of an examining physician designated by the public safety committee for such purpose appears from such physical examination incapable of performing appropriate duties in the department with efficiency and safety art iii  2 1964   applicantsexamination any examinations written oral and physical prescribed by the public safety committee where more than one candidate applies for appointment at the same time shall be competitive as between the candidates and appointment shall be made from among those who have passed the examinations art iii  3 1964   probation period each applicant to be selected as aforesaid shall be required to serve for a probationary period of one year during such period he or she shall be assigned to regular duty in the department if the mayor and council during such period shall determine in its discretion that he or she does not possess the ability and character for regular membership in the department or the necessity of hisher employment no longer exists he or she shall be dismissed such dismissal shall completely terminate hisher services art iii  4 1964   gradessalaries the grades salaries and compensation of the paid members of the department shall be fixed and determined by the mayor and council art iii  5 1964   tenure of officeremoval from officereduction of personnel the paid officers and paid fire fighters employed in the department shall severally hold their respective offices and continue in their respective employments during good behavior and efficiency and no person shall be removed from office or employment in the paid department for any cause other than incapacity misconduct or disobedience of the regulations of the department which may be established from time to time as provided in the regulation of the department  provided however that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent the reduction in personnel of the department when the mayor and council shall determine that the public welfare so requires art iii  6 1964   chief may suspend from duty the chief shall have the authority to suspend from duty pending a final hearing of charges any member of the department for incapacity misconduct or disobedience of the regulations of the department any member so suspended from duty shall not return to duty until directed by the mayor and council or the public safety committee thereof the chief shall immediately prepare and present charges as hereinafter provided art iii  7 1964   procedure for suspending removing fining reducing in office or grade no member of the department shall be suspended removed fined or reduced in grade until a written charge of the cause of complaint shall have been preferred against a member of the department signed by the person making the charge and filed in the office of the borough clerk and a copy thereof served upon such person within fifteen days after the filing thereof and b the charge has been publicly examined by the public safety committee and by the mayor and council upon reasonable notice to the person charged which examination shall commence not less than fifteen days nor more than thirty days after such copy of charges has been served then any member of the department may be suspended removed fined or reduced in his or her office or in his or her grade if such charges are substantiated however for any dereliction of duty for which a penalty less than suspension removal fine or reduction in office or in grade may be appropriate the chief may impose an appropriate penalty art iii  8 1964   special services all applications for special services must be referred to the chief no special duty shall be performed by paid employees of the department without direct authority in each instance from the chief art iii  9 1964   outside jobsabsence from duty the paid members of the department shall not engage in any business or occupation that interferes with their attention to their duties in the department or handicaps them in the performance of their duties in the department and no member of the department shall absent himself from duty without the permission of the chief art iii  10 1964   political activities no paid member of the department shall actively engage in electioneering or other proceedings of a political or party nature  nor shall he or she be present at the polls of any election except such reasonable time as may be required by him or her for the purpose of voting or unless he or she shall be directed by the chief to be present for purposes of fire prevention art iii  11 1964   volunteersapplication for appointment any person desiring appointment as a volunteer fire fighter shall make written application therefor to the chief art iv  1 1964   volunteersappointmentdismissal on the recommendation of the chief volunteer fire fighters may be appointed to the department by the mayor and council and shall hold office until they resign or are discharged with or without cause by the mayor and council art iv  2 1964   violationspenalties a no person shall raise create or continue a false alarm of fire under penalty upon conviction of a fine not to exceed twentyfive dollars for each offense or of imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed thirty days b no person shall drive any vehicle over any hose or other fire apparatus under penalty upon conviction of a fine not to exceed twentyfive dollars for each offense or of imprisonment in the county jail for a term not to exceed thirty days art v  1 1964   protection of propertyuse of fire hydrants a in case of a fire occurring in any dwelling house or other building within the limits of the borough the fire department shall have full charge of the extinguishing of such fire on arrival at the scene thereof and no person shall in any way interfere with or attempt to serve in any capacity in the matter of extinguishing such fire except under the authority and control and subject to the orders of the officers of the fire department b no person other than those specifically authorized and empowered by the mayor and council of the borough either individually or as officers or members of an authorized fire company or organization shall in any way open close or interfere with any one of the public fire hydrants within the limits of the borough c the constables and marshals of the borough shall be authorized and directed in case of fire occurring within the limits of the borough to man and take charge of fire hydrants in the vicinity of the fire and to prevent the interference by any unauthorized person or persons with such fire hydrants d in case of fire occurring within the limits of the borough no person other than those authorized as a fire fighter in accordance with this section shall come within the space of one hundred feet of the building in which the fire may occur or such other limits as may be fixed by the proper officers of the duly authorized fire company or organization e any person persons or corporation violating any of the provisions of this section shall be liable to a penalty of five dollars for each offense  1924   1899 department of public safety establishedpowers and pertaining to the department of public safety and its divisions c promulgation and enforcement of such administrative rules as in its judgment may from time to time be necessary for the efficient safety and recommendations to the mayor and council of such persons as they may deem suited for such positions  1982   organization a purpose it is the belief of the mayor and members of the council that creation of a department of public safety will 1 permit more effective leadership and administration  2 establish a single point of responsibility which will improve relationship with the borough council communications  3 increase flexibility in assigning tasks to public safety personnel  4 eliminate duplicative functions and enable consolidation of duties to achieve greater efficiency and economy in the public safety area  5 improve relationship between all members of the police and fire divisions of the department of public safety it is in the best interest of the residents and government of the borough b establishment there is created the department of public safety which shall consist of 1 police uniform division  2 detective division  3 fire division  4 administrative service division c office of director of public safety there is created the office of director of public safety d the director of public safety appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council shall be the chief administrative officer responsible and accountable for all aspects of public safety in the borough the director shall have such authority as is necessary to carry out the purpose of the department subject to the public safety committee supervision including the authority to 1 promulgate rules regulations and operating procedures subject to approval of the public safety committee for all divisions of the department  2 supervise the implementation of work schedules of all personnel of the department  3 prepare necessary budgets for all divisions of the department and be responsible for all financial matters pertaining to the department  4 assume responsibility for all personnel matters of the department including supervision of training establishing employment standards enforcement of discipline maintenance of personnel records of all department employees  5 provide such technical and other assistance as is necessary to the divisions for their proper functions  1982   police uniform division the police uniform division shall be headed by a superior police officer of the police divisions appointed by the mayor with the approval of the borough council the division shall consist of such additional officers and patrol officers as may be necessary as determined by the director of public safety upon the recommendations of the chief if any and the approval of the mayor and council to efficiently fulfill the duties assigned to the division this division will be responsible for the conduct and operation of the main police desk  1982   detective division a the detective division shall be headed by a superior officer of the police divisions appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council the division shall consist of such additional officers and patrol officers as may be necessary as determined by the director of public safety upon the recommendations of the chief if any and the approval of the mayor and council to efficiently fulfill the duties assigned to the division the officer in charge shall receive the salary designated by ordinance for his or her rank b the officer in charge of the detective division is particularly charged with the prevention of crime and required investigation of criminal offenses in the borough the detection and arrest of criminal offenders the locating of missing persons the recovery of lost or stolen property proper cooperation with other law enforcement agencies the proper conduct of fugitive requisition proceedings the responsibility of giving and providing vigilant scrutiny to and taking proper cognizance of all conditions relating to or tending toward the fostering of crime including gambling in any form and any other matter which the director of public safety shall determine are the special duties of the detective bureau any other officer or patrol officer assigned to the bureau shall assist the officer in charge in all matters c the grade of detective shall be of a temporary nature and shall apply to patrol officers when assigned by the director of public safety to the detective bureau of the division  1982   administrative services division the critical incident management in the borough of glen ridge county of essex a the president of the united states in homeland security presidential directive hspd5 directed the secretary of the department of homeland security to develop and administer a national incident management system nims which would provide consistent nationwide approach for federal state local and tribal governments to work together more effectively and efficiently to prevent prepare for respond to and answer from domestic incidents regardless of cause size or complexity b richard j cody acting governor of the state of new jersey in executive order 50 ordered and directed that there is established an incident management system in new jersey which shall be the national management system nims and that nims shall be the state standard for incident management and it shall be used for all emergencies incidents in the state and all first responders shall complete the nims awareness course national incident management system nims c executive order 50 additionally ordered and directed all county and municipal offices of emergency management to incorporate the nims into county andor municipal emergency operations plan eop during the next update to said eop pursuant to njsa appa 9432 and all responses conducted pursuant to the state eop or any county or municipal eop shall be conducted in accordance with the nims and all first responders shall annually participate in multidiscipline exercises and drills that utilize nims d the collective input and guidance from federal state local and tribal homeland security partners has been and will continue to be vital to the development effective implementation and utilization of a comprehensive nims e it is necessary and desirable that all federal state local and tribal emergencies agencies and personnel coordinate their efforts to effectively and efficiently provide the highest levels of incident management f to facilitate the most efficient and effective incident management it is critical that federal state local and tribal organizations utilize standardized terminology standardized organizational structures interoperability communications consolidation action plans unified command structures uniform personnel qualifications standards uniform standards for planning training and exercising comprehensive resource management and designated incident facilities during emergencies or disasters g the nims standardize procedures for managing personnel communications facilities and resources will improve the states and the county of essex ability to utilize federal funding to enhance local and state readiness maintain first responder safety and streamline incident management process h the incident command system components of nims are already an integral part of various management activities throughout the state including current emergency management training programs i the national commission on terrorist attacks 911 commission recommended adoption of a standardized incident command system j be it resolved by the mayor and the borough council of the borough of glen ridge in the county of essex in the state of new jersey that the national incident management system nims be and adopted and established as the standard for all incident management in the borough of glen ridge county of essex and in the state of new jersey and shall be utilized for all emergencies incidents  planning board definitions whenever a term is used in this chapter which is defined in njsa d1 et seq such term is intended to the number of days a fulltime borough employee shall be allowed during a calendar year accumulation of vacation time shall not be permitted except as set forth in this chapter a in the first year of fulltime employment one day for each month of employment not to exceed ten days no vacation time shall be granted until the employee has completed six months of satisfactory service unless the needs of the borough require a deviation from this rule b commencing the first full year of employment and each year thereafter tenth year of employment ten days per year c commencing with the eleventh year of employment and each year thereafter fifteenth year of employment thirteen days per year d commencing with the sixteenth year of employment and each year thereafter twentieth year of employment eighteen days per year e commencing with the twentyfirst year of employment and each year thereafter twenty days per year f the head of one or more department shall be entitled to five vacation days in addition to the number of days to which he or she would otherwise be entitled in accordance with the foregoing schedule g the employees anniversary date of employment must fall on or before june 30th of each year to be eligible for the number of vacation days at each level if said anniversary date falls on or after july 1st the additional vacation entitlement becomes effective in the next ensuing calendar year  1978  1964   police and fire department vacation days members of the paid police and fire departments shall be granted twelve working days off in each year in addition to the vacation days set forth in such days need not be granted by the chiefs of the departments in conjunction with the regular vacation days set forth in this chapter  1964   vacation schedulesarrangement vacation schedules shall be arranged by the head of each department subject to the approval of the borough administrator having due regard to the needs of the borough seniority of the employee and as far as possible the wishes of the employee for the efficient operation of the borough vacation days may be scheduled on mondays and fridays no more than once per calendar month and no more than six times in any one calendar year each monday or friday taken shall count as one time for the purpose of aggregation of time where in any calendar year the vacation or any part thereof is not granted by reason of pressure of borough affairs and with the approval of the borough administrator prior to the close of the calendar year in which the vacation time was not utilized such vacation period or part thereof not granted shall accumulate and shall be granted during the succeeding year failure to use the accumulated vacation time in the succeeding calendar year will result in the loss of the accumulated time by the employee department heads shall be responsible for reporting vacation schedules to the borough clerk as soon as possible after approval of same by the borough administrator as aforementioned   1978  1964   sick leave policy a 1 as used in this section sick leave means paid leave that may be granted to each fulltime borough employee who or injury becomes incapacitated to a degree that makes it impossible for him or her to perform the duties of his or her position or who is quarantined by a physician because he or she has been exposed to a contagious disease time and fulltime temporary employees are not eligible for sick leave 2 a certificate from the borough physician or the employees own physician may be required as sufficient proof of the need for sick leave in case of sick leave due to a contagious disease or exposure to same a certificate from the department of health shall be required 3 commencing  for existing employees and with the date of employment of each new employee employees shall accumulate sick leave at the rate of one and onequarter days per month for fulltime employees 4 sick leave can be accumulated to a maximum of two hundred days commencing with  5 extension of sick leave beyond the maximum days allowed by this section may be allowed by resolution of the borough council 6 accumulated sick leave may be used by an employee for personal illness illness in the employees immediate family which requires the employees attendance upon the ill person quarantine restrictions pregnancy or disabling injuries the term immediate family for the purposes of this subparagraph shall mean and refer only to the employees spouse child parent or unmarried brother or unmarried sister 7 all absences on account of illness or disability shall be reported immediately by or for the employee to the employees immediate supervisor if the supervisor cannot be reached promptly the report should then be made to the office of the borough clerk without further delay every absence on account of illness or disability in excess of three days must be certified by a written statement from the attending physician if requested by the employees department head or the borough council 8 sick leave with pay will not be allowed under the following conditions a if the employee when under medical care fails to carry out the orders of the attending physician b if in the opinion of the borough physician the employee is ill or disabled because of selfimposed contributory causes or actions occasioned by bad habits c if in the opinion of the borough physician the disability or illness is not of sufficient severity to justify the employees absence from duty 9 sick leave cannot be allowed for ordinary dental care nor for the services of an oculist for normal eye care 10 upon retirement terminal leave shall be granted for a total number of weeks or parts thereof equal to the then unused accumulated days of sick leave divided by five b 1 when a fulltime borough employee is injured in the line of duty the borough council may pursuant to njsa 8 and 9 pass a resolution giving the employee up to one years leave of absence with pay when such action is taken the employee shall not be charged any sick leave time for time lost due to such particular injury 2 any employee who has been granted a leave of absence with pay as a result of injury in the line of duty and qualifies for payments under workmens compensation weekly benefits shall during the period the employee is receiving such weekly benefits be entitled only to the difference between his or her regular salary and the workmens compensation payments c 1 in the event of a death in the employees immediate family as defined in a6 the department head may grant the employee three days leave of absence with pay if deemed necessary 2 deviation from the foregoing may be granted by a member of the council under special circumstances d an employee upon retirement from employment by reason of age length of service or disability as permitted and described under the laws of the state of new jersey regarding the various employee retirement systems shall be permitted compensatory time off to onehalf of any unused sick leave accumulated during the employees service to the borough to a maximum of one hundred days e a separate time record file shall be kept on each employee of every member of the paid fire department rank of lieutenant  and all field personnel of the public works and water departments position of field supervisor shall be paid either overtime pay or given compensatory time off for overtime work performed by the members of the police and fire departments during times of emergencies as defined in njsa 1212 and for overtime work performed by the personnel of the public works and water departments which is necessary for the health and welfare of the residents of the borough at the following rate schedule 1 for the police department computed biweekly in excess of eighty hours at an hourly rate of one and onehalf the officers hourly rate not including longevity computed by the officers annual salary divided by two thousand eighty hours 2 for the fire department computed biweekly in excess of eightyfour hours at an hourly rate of one and onehalf the members hourly rate not including longevity computed by the officers annual salary divided by two thousand one hundred eightyfour hours 3 for the public works department computed biweekly in excess of eighty hours at an hourly rate of one and onehalf the employees hourly rate not including longevity computed by the employees annual salary divided by two thousand eighty hours except that when an emergency requires public works employees to work the following holidays new years day  memorial day  july 4th  labor day  thanksgiving day or christmas day  said employee shall be compensated at double the hourly rate computed as aforementioned 4 for the water department computed biweekly in excess of eighty hours at an hourly rate of one and onehalf the employees hourly rate not including longevity computed by the employees annual salary divided two thousand eighty hours except that double the employees hourly rate shall be paid when said employee is required to work on any of the six holidays listed in subparagraph 3 b overtime pay shall not be made part of the employees regular pay for pension purposes c in computing overtime compensation the nearest onehalf hour shall be the smallest fraction of an hour to be reported d department heads are charged with the responsibility of administering overtime regulations that are consistent with this section must be set up as a guideline periodic review of overtime requirements shall be taken with a view toward devising methods to accomplish the work during regular work shifts e department heads will submit a report to the borough council at the close of each month said report to summarize and justify the overtime paid to each employee named and the purpose for overtime in the preceding month f clerical employees who incur overtime in excess of eighty hours computed biweekly at an hourly rate of one and onehalf the employees hourly rate not including longevity computed by the employees annual salary divided by two thousand eighty hours g any request for deviation form any subsection of this of the laws of 196 entitled an act to authorize the governing body of the borough of glen ridge in the county of essex to waive in certain cases the provisions of the general statutes which require domestic violence intervention team statement of policy in 199 the new jersey legislature passed the prevention of domestic violence act of 199 njsa 2c 2517 et seq the act having determined that domestic violence is a serious crime against society with victims from all social and economic backgrounds pursuant to the act crisis intervention teams of trained residents can be formed to assist police authorities in dealing with domestic violence cases the glen ridge domestic violence intervention team would assist victims of domestic violence by providing information in available resources and referrals and acting as a liaison with the police and other agencies as appropriate part 2000   establishment of teamqualification for membershipappointment coordinator there is created the borough of glen ridge domestic violence crisis intervention team the team shall consist of an unlimited number of volunteers who shall be at least twentyone years of age all team members shall serve without compensation interested persons shall complete an application form supplied by the borough be fingerprinted by the police department and subject to a background check members of the team shall be appointed by resolution of the borough council upon recommendations of the mayor the borough council shall also by resolution and upon recommendation by the mayor appoint certain team members as coordinators all coordinators and other team members shall be supervised by the police department and shall serve at the discretion of the borough council   part 2000   training program no person may serve as a team member unless heshe shall have first completed a fortyhour training program specializing in domestic violence crisis intervention team matters this training further provides confidentiality protection to the member in comportment with njsa 2a 84a22 et seq part 2000   functions and duties the functions and duties of the team shall include but not limited to a meeting with victims of domestic violence to provide support compassion and advice  b providing information on available resources appropriate agencies hot lines and the like and serving as a liaison with police and other agencies as appropriate  c such other functions and duties as may be established by the police department part 2000   annual report the police department shall prepare and submit to the mayor and borough council an annual report summarizing the activities of the team and any recommendations it sees fit to make part 2000 title 3  revenue and finance chapters claims against the borough form of claims all claims against the borough shall be presented in writing fully itemized on such voucher forms as shall be provided for that purpose and all vouchers shall be certified to by the claimant  1963    checking of claims all vouchers shall be reviewed and checked by or under the direction of the borough official in charge of the department responsible for the claim and if found correct the official shall complete the officers certification thereon it shall be the duty of the chief financial officer or his or her designated representative to audit warrant and make recommendations on all claims bills and demands to ascertain that proper administrative procedures have been followed and that the goods andor services are consistent with an existing contract or purchase order all vouchers shall thereafter be presented to the borough administrator who if satisfied with the propriety of the claim shall so note hisher approval and refer the voucher to the borough treasurer the treasurer shall then prepare checks and bill list which shall then be forwarded to the borough clerk for presentation to the mayor and borough council at a meeting of said body the governing body shall approve payment or shall state its reason for rejecting the same any disproved claim shall be sent to the borough administrator with the reason for refusal and instructions the borough clerk shall record all claims in the official minutes together with the governing bodys disposition of the same such records shall be available for public inspection vouchers for statutory payments payrolls investments utilities and other periodic recurring payments required to be made by the borough of glen ridge between formal public meetings of the governing body may be certified by the borough administrator and sent to the treasurer for disbursement all such payments shall require ratification by the governing body at the formal public meeting of the governing body next following payment  1963    presentation to council the vouchers shall thereafter be presented to the chairperson of the council committee having primary interest in the department responsible for the claim who if satisfied with the propriety of the claim shall approve and return the same to the borough clerk for referral to the finance committee  1963   approval by finance committee a the chairperson of the finance committee or in the chairpersons absence some other member of the committee shall examine all vouchers referred by the borough clerk and if approved such approval shall be noted upon the vouchers and the vouchers returned to the borough clerk for presentation to the council for approval and authorization to pay the same b all vouchers approved for payment pursuant to the foregoing shall be presented to the council at a regular meeting of said body  5 1963   approval of claims council approval of the claims and authorization to draw the warrants to pay the same contained in regulations promulgated by the board of health of the borough  1980   license fees the annual fees for licenses for each such food and beverage vending machine for the purpose of raising revenue for inspection for regulation and control to be paid annually to this municipality are fixed as follows a the fee for each such vending machine shall be at the rate of one dollar per penny calculated at the highest denomination of coin required in said machine provided that there shall be a maximum fee of fifty dollars for any such machine b each machine having a separate coin slot shall be individually licensed  1980   posting requirements each vending machine shall have attached to it a sticker with the following legend this vending machine is licensed by the glen ridge board entitled garage sale attic sale rummage sale or flea market sale or any similar casual sale of tangible personal property which is advertised by a means whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of said sale goods is meant to include any goods or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder and which is owned by the licensee occupant means owner or lessee of the premises  1974   license required it is unlawful to conduct a garage sale in the borough without first filing with the borough clerk the information hereinafter specified and obtaining from such clerk a license so to do to be known as a garage sale license the fee for such license is fixed at two dollars  1974   issuance of licensedisplay requirements a such license shall be issued as to any one premises only once within a twelvemonth period and no such license shall be issued for more than two consecutive calendar days b each license issued under this chapter must be prominently displayed on the premises and visible from the street upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the licensed sale  1974   information required by clerk the information to be filed with the borough clerk pursuant to this chapter shall be as follows a name of person firm group corporation association or organization conducting said sale  b name of owner or lessee of the premises on which said sale is to be conducted  c location at which sale is to be conducted  d number of days of sale  e date and nature of any past sale  f sworn statement or affirmation by the person signing that the information therein given is full and true and known to him or her to be so  1974   conduct of sale the person to whom such license is issued and the owner or tenant of the premises on which such sale or activity is conducted shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of good order and decorum on the premises during all hours of such sale or activity no such persons shall permit any loud or boisterous conduct on said premises nor permit vehicles to impede the passage of traffic on any roads or streets in the area of such premises all such persons shall obey the reasonable orders of any member of the police or fire departments of the borough in order to maintain the public health safety and welfare all licensed premises shall at all times be subject to such reasonable rules as may be made from time to time by the borough council and shall be subject to inspection at all times by the building inspector chief of police and fire chief or any of their agents or any other duly authorized representative of the borough  1974   hours of sale all garage sales shall be conducted between the hours of nine am and five pm only  1974   posting of signsplace of sale a no signs for advertising or directing customers are to be posted on any place other than the premises where the sale is to be held the sign shall not exceed two feet by two feet in size and shall not be placed on the premises earlier than one week prior to the sale and must be removed within twentyfour hours after the sale has terminated b sales as defined and permitted under this chapter shall be conducted on the licensed premises only in the dwelling garage or rear yard  1974   regulations for sale items it is unlawful for any person to offer for sale mattresses bedsprings cots lounges and sofas in any garage sale authorized under this chapter without first complying with the appropriate section of njsa 1 with respect to the labeling sterilizing disinfecting of said mattresses bedsprings cots lounges and sofas  1974   persons and sales excepted the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales a persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction  b persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials  c any person selling or advertising for sale an item or items of personal property which are specifically named or described in the advertisement and which separate items do not exceed five in number  d any sale conducted by any merchant of mercantile or other business establishment from or at a place of business wherein such sale would be permitted by the zoning regulations of the borough or under the protection of the nonconforming use section thereof or any other sale conducted by a manufacturer dealer or vendor and which sale would be conducted from properly zoned premises and not otherwise prohibited in the ordinances  e any bona institution claiming such exemption such exemption may be permitted by resolution of the borough council after application by any of the aforementioned types of organizations  1974   enforcement this arising from hisher own personal knowledge and if a violation is found to exist heshe shall prosecute a complaint before the local municipal court pursuant to the provisions of this chapter it shall be the duty of the police department to bring to the attention of the building inspector for further investigation any violation of this chapter of which the police department becomes aware during the delivery thereof to the person to be notified or by being deposited in the united states post office in a sealed envelope certified mail postage prepaid addressed to such person to be notified at the and deliberation by the board of health the complaint may be dismissed or if the governing body concludes that the charges have been sustained and substantiated it may revoke cancel or suspend the license held by the licensee c if any such license shall have been revoked neither the holder thereof nor any person acting for him directly or indirectly shall be entitled to another license to carry commercial landscapers purpose an ordinance to add this chapter of the the borough of glen ridge establishing requirements for commercial landscapers to control noise in the borough of glen ridge so as to protect public health safety and welfare and to prescribe penalties for the failure to comply  2006   definitions as used in this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings indicated annual fee means the fee charged by and payable to the municipal clerk of the borough of glen ridge to obtain a license as a landscaper annual license means license issued by the municipal clerk of the borough of glen ridge for the period starting october 1st and ending september 30th for the purposes stated customer means anyone who employs the services of a landscaper to perform the services of maintaining cutting cleaning or raking property within the borough of glen ridge landscape contractor means the same meaning as landscaper landscaper means a person or persons doing business with residential or commercial customers for the purpose of maintaining cutting cleaning raking or performing similar activities on property within the borough of glen ridge vehicle means any vehicle required to be registered with the new jersey department of motor vehicles for use on local roads and highways and used by a landscaper in the performance of his or her work in the borough of glen ridge  2006   license required all landscapers utilizing a truck van or trailer for landscaping services within the borough of glen ridge shall be required to obtain a license in order to offer their services in the borough of glen ridge a license shall be required for each vehicle the landscaper owns or operates within the borough of glen ridge such license shall be obtained from the municipal clerk prior to october 1 of each calendar year such licenses shall terminate september 30 proof of licensor will be demonstrated by the issuance and the display of a decal which will be issued to each licensee and displayed in each vehicle the landscaper owns or operates in the borough of glen ridge  2006   application for license a all applications for landscaping licenses shall be in writing on failure to license dogpenalty all persons owning or having the care custody or control of a dogs shall license said dogs during the month of january of each year in accordance with the statutes of the state of new jersey failure to license said dogs during january will result in a tendollar penalty being levied and ten dollars for each subsequent month failure to license said dogs by april 1st of each year will result in the matter being placed in the jurisdiction of the municipal court and shall be subject to a fine not exceeding fifty dollars upon conviction said fine shall be in addition to the monthly late penalty b 1982 a 1941   running at largeprohibited activities each and every person owning harboring keeping or having charge of any male or female dog in the borough shall a prevent such dog from running at large upon any public highway street alley park or other public place in the borough at any time  b prevent such dog from being on any public highway street avenue alley park or other public place in the borough at any time unless such dog be accompanied and controlled by a person of the age of seven years or over and be securely confined by an adequate leash not more than eight feet in length  c prevent such dog from running at large in the borough upon the lands of any person other than the person owning harboring keeping or having charge of such dog without the consent of the owner of such lands  d prevent such dog from injuring or damaging any vegetable garden flower garden lawn plant tree shrubbery grounds or other property of any person other than the person owning harboring keeping or have charge of such dog  e prevent such dog from barking crying whining howling or otherwise disturbing the peace or quiet of the neighborhood or sleep of any person for any unreasonable length of time  f prevent such dog from causing any injury to any person  1962   impoundment any male or female dog that shall be found running at large upon any public highway street avenue alley park or other public place in the borough at any time or that shall be found at any time doing any of the other things mentioned in which the person owning harboring keeping or having charge of such dog is required by this chapter to prevent shall forthwith be taken and impounded by the police or dog warden of the borough and shall be kept and confined for a period of seven days next thereafter and shall then be humanely destroyed or otherwise disposed of according to law  provided however that within said period of seven days the police or dog warden of the borough shall release such dog to the owner or other person entitled to the possession thereof upon claim therefor and upon payment of the expense of keeping such dog while so impounded at a reasonable rate per day  and provided further that if any dog at the time of such taking and impounding thereof shall wear any registration tag collar or other harness by means of which the police or dog warden of the borough are enabled to ascertain the name of the person owning harboring keeping or having charge of such dog said police or dog warden shall promptly serve written notice upon such person that such dog has been taken and impounded under the provisions of this chapter which notice shall be sufficiently served if the same be delivered to such person or be left at such persons usual or last known place of abode or be forwarded by mail with prepaid first class postage to such person at his usual or last known place of abode and such dog meanwhile shall remain impounded for not less than seven days next after the service of said notice unless such dog be sooner claimed and released as hereinabove provided  1962   creation of nuisanceowner responsibility a no person owning or having the care custody or control of a dog shall knowingly or negligently permit such dog to commit any nuisance and more particularly and without limiting the generality thereof any excretion of feces upon any public sidewalk or other thoroughfare or in or upon any public building or any public park or public playground  or on any private property without the permission of the owner of said property  nor shall any person omit to do any reasonable and proper act or omit to take any reasonable and proper precaution to prevent any such dog from committing a nuisance in on or upon any of the places or premises herein specified b any person owning harboring keeping or in charge of any dog which soils defiles defecates on or commits any nuisance on any common thoroughfare sidewalk passageway bypath play area park or any place where people congregate or walk or upon any public property whatsoever or upon any private property without the permission of the owner of such property shall immediately remove all feces deposited by such dog by any sanitary method approved by the local health authority  1980  1962   vicious dogpenalty a it is unlawful for any person to possess harbor or conceal a vicious dog or one suffering from a contagious disease or from the bites of another animal except under strict medical care  and a dog so affected shall be kept closely confined until pronounced cured by the attending veterinarian any person violating any of the provisions of this section upon conviction thereof shall be subject to a fine of up to one thousand dollars but not less than five hundred dollars andor up to ninety days imprisonment b any dog which has attacked or bitten any human being or which habitually attacks other dogs or domestic animals is hereby defined to be a vicious dog for the purposes of the section c it shall be the duty of the chief of police or the person designated by the chief of police to receive and cause to be investigated complaints against dogs when any dog complained of shall be deemed by the chief of police or his or her designee to be vicious he or she shall cause a complaint to be filed against the owner or person harboring such a dog and shall cause said complaint and summons to be served upon said owner or person harboring such dog for a hearing to be held before the municipal judge at which time said judge shall inquire into the facts and give all interested persons an opportunity to be heard under oath and to be represented by counsel d if the judge shall decide in accordance with the evidence before him or her that such dog complained of is vicious as defined by this section notice of such decision shall be given to the owner or person harboring such dog thereafter no such dog determined as aforesaid to be a vicious dog shall be permitted to run at large and that further the owner or person harboring such a dog shall have it securely muzzled and under leash at all times when out of doors the owner or person harboring any such vicious dog who shall suffer or permit such dog to run at large or be upon any street public or private place in the borough while not securely muzzled and on a leash shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter any persons found guilty of violating any provision of this section shall be subject to upon conviction thereof a fine of up to one thousand dollars but not less that five hundred dollars andor up to ninety days imprisonment e nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or impair the power of the borough of glen ridge or any officer or department to enforce any provisions of its charter or any other provisions of its code or regulations promulgated thereunder nor to prevent or punish violations thereof and the powers conferred by this chapter shall be in addition and supplemental to the powers conferred upon the borough by any other law or provision of the glen ridge if any clause sentence subdivision paragraph section or part of the ordinance codified in this chapter be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid such judgment shall not affect impair or invalidate the remainder thereof but shall be confined in its operation to the clause sentence subdivision paragraph section or part thereof directly involved in the controversy in which said judgment shall have been rendered  c 1982  1941   violationpenalty that any person who shall violate this chapter or any of the terms or provisions thereof or do any act or thing herein prohibited or neglect fail refuse to do any act or thing herein required to be done shall upon conviction thereof before the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer authorized to hear and determine the matter forfeit and pay such fine not exceeding the sum of twentyfive dollars for the first offense and not exceeding the sum of one hundred dollars for any subsequent offense as shall be imposed by the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer in his or her discretion or if the party so convicted be a natural person be imprisoned in the borough jail or county jail for such a term not exceeding ten days as the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer in his or her discretion shall determine  provided however that the municipal magistrate or other judicial officer shall have power in his or her discretion to impose sentence of both fine and imprisonment not exceeding the maximum limits fixed in this section   1962 cats definitions for purposes of this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings set forth below cat means and includes any member of the domestic feline species male female or neutered which has attained the age of seven months or which possesses a set of permanent teeth certificate of exemption means a certificate issued by a duly authorized veterinarian stating that because of an infirmity other physical condition or regimen therapy the inoculation of a particular cat against rabies is deemed inadvisable inoculated against rabies means inoculated by a duly licensed veterinarian with a rabies vaccine of a type approved by and administered in accordance with the recommendations of the united states department of agriculture and the united states department of human services owner of a cat means and includes any person who has a right of property in or custody of a cat who harbors or maintains a cat or who knowingly permits a cat to remain on or about any premises occupied by that person within the borough resident of the borough means a person whose ordinary dwelling place is within the borough  1991   inoculation against rabiesrequired a every resident of the borough who is the owner of a cat shall have and keep such cat inoculated against rabies at all times unless a certificate of exemption issued as to such cat is currently effective b upon the request of any authorized agent of the glen ridge board of health or upon the request of any police officer or animal control officer a resident of the borough who is the owner of a cat shall provide evidence that such cat has been inoculated against rabies and that the period during which such inoculation is considered to be effective has not expired c exemption the provision of this section shall not apply to a cat being kept in a pet shop or in a veterinary establishment  1991   impoundment of catsprovisions and regulations a any person appointed for the purpose by the board of health of the borough shall take in custody and impound or cause to be taken into custody and impounded and thereafter destroyed or offered for adoption as provided in this section 1 any cat off the premises of the owner or of the person keeping or harboring said cat which said official or his or her agent or agents have reason to believe is a stray cat  2 any female cat in season off the premises of the owner or of the person keeping or harboring said cat  3 any cat or other animal which is suspected to be rabid  4 any cat or other animal off the premises of the owner reported to or observed by a certified animal control officer to be ill injured or creating a threat to public health safety or welfare or otherwise interfering with the enjoyment of property b if any animal so seized wears a collar or harness having inscribed thereon or attached thereto the name and address of any person or the owner or the person keeping or harboring said animal is known any person authorized by the governing body shall forthwith serve on the person whose address is given on the collar or on the owner or the person keeping or harboring said animal if known a notice in writing stating that the animal has been seized and will be liable to be offered for adoption or destroyed if not claimed within seven days after the service of the notice c a notice under this section may be served either by delivering it to the person on whom it is to be served or by leaving it at the persons usual or last known place of abode or at the address given on the collar or by forwarding it by post in a prepaid letter addressed to that person at his or her usual or last known place of abode or to the address given on the collar d any person authorized by the board of health may cause an animal to be destroyed in a manner causing as little pain as possible and consistent with the provisions of njsa 19 or offered for adoption seven days after seizure  provided that 1 notice is given as set forth above and the animal remains unclaimed  or 2 the owner or person keeping or harboring the animal has not claimed the animal and paid all expenses incurred by reason of its detention including maintenance costs  or 3 the owner or person keeping or harboring a cat which was unlicensed at the time of seizure does not produce a license and registration tag for the cat e at the time of adoption the right of ownership in the animal shall transfer to the new owner no cat or other animal so caught and detained or procured obtained sent or brought to a pound or shelter shall be sold or otherwise made available for the purpose of experimentation any person who sells or otherwise makes available any such cat or other animal for the purpose of experimentation shall be guilty of a disorderly persons offense f after observation any animal seized under this section suspected of being rabid shall immediately be reported to the health officer  1991   violationpenalty any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall upon conviction thereof be punished as provided in general penalty of this code  2005  title 8  health and safety chapters alarm systems findings the borough council finds that the existence within the borough of external audible alarm systems which do not contain automatic shutoff systems permits the continuing emission of loud alarm signals without termination and that in the event of unavailability of those able to control and terminate the alarm persons in the vicinity are exposed to these loud noises for lengthy and indefinite periods without means of obtaining relief  that this condition is inimical to the public health and welfare and to the wellbeing of persons within the borough  and that lengthy emission of alarm signals is not necessary to the legitimate purposes of the property owner or occupant the council further finds that many residents and commercial entities have installed burglar fire and other warning devices within their residences or buildings and that false alarms from said devices require a response and the unproductive diversion of personnel and equipment from their public safety function within the borough  1984   purpose the purpose of this chapter is to establish regulations concerning the operation and maintenance of certain alarm systems within the borough and to provide penalties for violations of any of the provisions set forth in this chapter  1984   definitions for the purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply alarm console means the control panels in public safety headquarters giving alarm indications and locations alarm device means any type of alarm actuating equipment which provides warning of intrusion fire smoke burglary flood or like peril including a direct alarm dial alarm or local alarm alarm system means the installation in or on one or more buildings of one or more alarm devices dial alarm means the type of device which employs an automatic dialing system precoded to connect with a telephone in public safety headquarters direct alarm means an alarm device which has a direct line to an alarm console false alarm means the activation of an alarm system where an emergency does not exist false alarms will not include activations caused by public utility interruptions where such interruptions have been reported to the public safety department  or those activations caused by a natural event or a malfunction of the public safety department equipment  or those activations caused by testing or repair of the system provided the public safety department has been notified before such tests or repairs commence local alarm means any alarm device other than a direct alarm or dial alarm which when activated produces an external emergency signal person means any natural person partnership or corporation limited partnership association business club or organization  1984   notification before tests or repairs all persons responsible for an alarm system within the borough shall notify the public safety department before tests or repairs of the system commence and after completion of the same  1984   registration of alarm system any person that owns maintains or has on hisher property an alarm system with the borough of glen ridge shall be required to register annually with the borough police department the existence of the alarms alarms installed and in service must be registered by april 15th of each year alarms installed and put into service after april 15th of any year must be registered within fortyfive days of installation and commencement of service if registration is not received by the applicable time the alarm owner will be subject to the penalty prescribed in registration forms will be made available at the public safety building and the following information will be required as part of the alarms registration the location of any alarm device so owned or operated the type of device the name address and telephone number of at least two persons who can be reached in case of an emergency or malfunction of the alarm device in order that the device can be shut off or temporarily disconnected the person owning maintaining or having any such alarm system on hisher property may but is not required to leave a key to the property with the public safety department to enable a member of the department to turn off the device when necessary in the event of any change in the provided information the person responsible for the device shall submit to the public safety department in writing such revised information within thirty days of any such change  2000   connection with public safety department alarm console any connection to the public safety department alarm console shall be of a type inspected and approved by the contractor servicing the public safety department alarm console at the time of installation of the alarm device it is the responsibility of the person causing the alarm device to be installed to arrange with the approved contractor for the payment of the connection fees and charges which prices shall be available at public safety headquarters the borough and the glen ridge board of education shall not be charged with console maintenance fees  1984   alarm regulations all dial alarms installed subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall conform with the following a dial alarms shall be coded to select a special number assigned by the public safety department no such device shall dial any other telephone number on the police switchboard  b prerecorded messages must be approved by the public safety department as to content clarity length and the number of times the message is to be repeated  c the device shall be provided with an automatic line seizure feature in the event the assigned telephone line is busy with another call  d all such devices shall be capable of being disconnected by the owner to permit a call to the public safety switchboard in the event of a false alarm  e all components of such equipment must be maintained by the owner or operator in good repair  f the owner or operator shall pay to the borough a fee to be established annually by resolution of the council sufficient to amortize the cost of the special telephone line or lines required by these devices such fee shall be paid not later than january 15th for each calendar year or any part thereof in the event installation of the system is made during a calendar year payment of the fee shall be made at or before time of installation and shall be prorated on a monthly basis  g in the event a person responsible for such device fails to comply with the requirements of this section relating to dial alarms the director of the public safety department or his or her designee shall issue a written demand to the person responsible for such device that the above requirements be complied with such demand shall specify the areas of noncompliance failure of such person to comply with such demand within ten days of the mailing of such written notification shall be deemed a violation of this chapter for which such person shall pay a penalty of five dollars for each day of noncompliance after such tenday period  1984   timing devices required all external audible alarms shall be equipped with a timing device that will automatically silence the external audible alarm within fifteen minutes after it is activated  1990  1984   false alarmpenalty the public safety department shall cause a record to be made of all false alarms in any twelvemonth period the following penalties shall apply to the person responsible for any alarm device a for the first second and third false alarms a written warning shall be issued b for the fourth and each subsequent false alarms there shall be imposed a penalty of fifty dollars for each such false alarm in addition an investigation shall be conducted by the public safety department as to the cause of such continued false alarms and upon a finding by the public safety department that there has been abuse or neglect in the operation or maintenance of any such alarm system and a failure to take remedial steps to avoid false alarms the director of the public safety department or his or her designee may require that the alarm device in the event of a direct alarm or dial alarm be disconnected from the public safety department headquarters for a limited or permanent time no such disconnection shall be made without giving the owner or operator of the alarm device at least ten days notice in writing of such intended disconnection in order to allow such person to appeal such determination to the public safety committee in order to show cause why such action should not be taken in the event such appeal is filed with the public safety committee within such tenday period in writing the public safety committee shall hold a hearing with reference to the matter and no disconnection shall be made until the appeal is decided by that body  2000   applicability the provisions of this chapter shall apply to alarm systems placed in service prior to or subsequent to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter  provided however that the owners or operators of existing alarm devices shall have thirty days from said effective date to provide the public safety department with the information required in this chapter  1984   violationpenalty this chapter shall be enforceable in the municipal court of the borough any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall for each offense be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars said fine shall be in addition to any penalty imposed by this chapter each incident shall be considered a separate violation c 1984  1984 garbage collection and disposal collection district established the territory or area contained
